head.headtext: Business records exception to hearsay rule

para.paratext: Under early Georgia law, parties to litigation were incompetent as witnesses. As a result, a “Shop Book Rule”[1] developed in a suit on account where the account books of the plaintiff were admitted into evidence if he had no clerk or the clerk was unavailable, the books were those of original entry, he usually kept correct books, and the books were free from suspicion of fraud. The Georgia legislature codified this rule in former GCA § 38-310. Later, the Business Records Act of 1952 (former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-14) did not specifically repeal the rule. In 1971, the Georgia Court of Appeals held that former GCA § 38-310 must yield to the Act of 1952.[2]

Most jurisdictions that enacted statutory exceptions to the hearsay rule for business entries followed either the federal statute[3] or the Uniform Business Records as Evidence Act.[4] In 1952, Georgia's Business Records Act, former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-14, combined features of both.
Now, under new O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(6), which mirrors Fed. R. Evid. 803(6), regular entries made in due course of business are admissible in evidence as an exception to the hearsay rule.

In the past, the entry offered into evidence was limited to a record of fact and not opinion or conjecture.[5] However, O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(6) now allows opinion testimony with qualification under O.C.G.A. § 24-7-701 (lay opinions) and O.C.G.A. § 24-7-702 (expert opinions).
The business records exception to the hearsay rule applies to all types of documents kept in the regular course of an established entity's operations.[6] O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(6) reads as follows:

Unless the source of information or the method of circumstances of preparation indicate lack of trustworthiness and subject to the provisions of chapter 7 of this title, a memorandum, report, record, or data compilation, in any form, of acts, events, conditions, opinions, or diagnoses, is (A)made at or near the time of the described acts, events, conditions, opinions, or diagnoses; (B) made by, or from information transmitted by, a person with personal knowledge and a business duty to report; (C) kept in the course of a regularly conducted business activity; and (D) it was the regular practice of that business activity to make the memorandum, report, record, or data compilation, all a shown by the testimony of the custodian or other qualified witness or by certification that by the testimony of the custodian or other qualified witness or by certification that complies with paragraph (11) or (12) of Code Section 24-9-902 or by any other statute permitting certification. The term “business” as used in this paragraph includes any business, institution, association, profession, occupation, and calling of every kind, whether or not conducted for profit. Public records and reports shall be admissible under paragraph (8) of this Code section and shall not be admissible under this paragraph.

Also, Fed. R. Evid. 803(7) and O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(7) provide for the admission of a record of regularly conducted activity “to prove the nonoccurrence or nonexistence of the matter.”[7] Georgia courts have held that business records are admissible to prove the absence of an entry.[8] Also, a witness who examined the records may testify about its absence.[9]

Historically, Georgia's statutory hearsay exception for business records received favorable judicial construction. The 1952 Act was a broad departure from previously fixed rules of evidence.[10] The rule, as written and construed, required that the records be made routinely or “in the regular course of business.”[11] “[E]vidence admitted under the business records exception should be ‘routine facts’ whose accuracy is not affected by ‘bias, judgment, and memory.’”[12]

The prior exclusion of records containing opinions and conclusions did not mean that business records had to be entirely objective or neutral. A self-serving declaration within the business record does not make it inadmissible.[13] The inclusion of such declarations goes to the credibility of the document, not its admissibility.
The records must be made at or near the time of the act, transaction, occurrence, or event described therein[14] and may not be made solely in anticipation of litigation.[15]

The actual business record or an admissible copy must be produced at trial. When the records themselves are not in evidence, a witness may not testify regarding the contents of business records.[16] Thus, a witness in a slip and fall case was erroneously allowed to testify about the times the floor was swept prior to the plaintiff's fall when such testimony was the witness's mere recollection of what was recorded on the store's “sweep card” and the card was not itself admitted into evidence.[17]

Various types of records[18] have been admitted under this exception, such as delivery tickets;[19] time sheets;[20] fingerprint cards;[21] freight manifests;[22] hospital records;[23] computer printouts;[24] videotape records;[25] phone call records, records of texts, and location of cell towers with the associated phone calls and texts;[26] an electronic security log;[27] and even prescription drug labels.[28] Police report narratives are now admissible as “matters observed pursuant to a duty imposed by law” under O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(8).

Examples of records held to be inadmissible as hearsay are: salary information provided verbally to the preparer of the record over the phone[29] and telephone messages as the contents were of a telephone conversation, “not an act, transaction, occurrence, or event.”[30] As stated by the Georgia Court of Appeals, “The Georgia statute does not prescribe the form or type of record to be admitted in evidence, providing merely for the admissibility of any ‘writing or record, whether in the form of an entry in a book or otherwise …,’ and vesting a wide discretion in the trial judge. Thus … our statute was intended to bring the realities of business and professional practice into the courtroom and should not be interpreted so as to destroy its obvious usefulness.”[31] However, a record created largely for purposes of litigation and not in the course of ordinary business is not admissible.[32]

In both federal and Georgia practice, a party must establish a foundation before a business entry may be introduced into evidence. This may be done through a witness familiar with the records and the method of making entries.[33] Also, O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(6) now allows a party to use a certified record in lieu of live testimony. A party intending to use an affidavit must give opposing parties written notice and make the record available to them prior to trial.[34] In some cases, the prosecution may offer certified records without a live witness.[35]

In Santana v. State,[36] the Georgia Court of Appeals explained that it is not necessary for the foundation witness to have been the one who made the records or kept them under his or her control. Rather, the witness must only “be able to testify that the record was made (1) in the regular course of business and (2) at the time of the event or within a reasonable time of the event.”[37] An offering party must provide written notice to the opposing party and make the underlying record available for inspection.[38]

Include a certification form complying with the statute with medical record requests, and make the declaration available for inspection sufficiently in advance of their offer into evidence to provide an adverse party with a fair opportunity to challenge such record and affidavit.

The witness's lack of personal knowledge regarding how the records were created affects the weight given to the evidence rather than rendering them inadmissible.[39] The trial judge, not the jury, determines if the proffering party has established sufficient foundation for admission of the records.[40] Additionally, on summary judgment, facts to support the foundation for the admission of a business record must be submitted (by way of affidavit or otherwise), or the evidence cannot be considered by the court.[41] Furthermore, where the records are submitted by affidavit, the affidavit will be disregarded to the extent the records upon which the affidavit is based have not been included for the court's consideration.[42]
The new business records exception utilizes the federal “integrated records rule” for foundation issues created when one business receives records from another business.
